newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST-Jan US industrial output to come off boil.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Jan US industrial output to come off boil.

text.p: Recent factory employment data suggest bubbling U.S. industrial output at the end of 1996 was probably reduced to a simmer in January, economists said.

In part, economists based their forecasts on an 18,000 rise in manufacturing jobs, combined with a drop in the factory workweek in January. Experts polled by Reuters, on average, expect industrial production to rise a tame 0.1 percent on the heels of a 0.7 percent increase in December.

"Overall, we're talking about a modest gain following two pretty impressive increases in November and December," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.
Industrial output rose 0.8 percent in November. The January numbers are due to be released by the Federal Reserve at 0915 EST/1415 GMT on Friday, February 14.

Other anecdotal evidence reflecting a partial reading on January business activity -- such as initial jobless claims, consumer confidence, and the Business Week production index -- point to a respectable reading, said Gary Thayer, senior economist at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc.
But despite resonably good automobile sales in January, economists said car manufacturing during the first month of 1997 may have fallen a little short of expectations.
"We think the (industrial production) number could be pretty good, but there is the wild card on car production," Thayer said.
Utilities' output could also be somewhat of a drag on the overall industrial yield in January, Karydakis said.
Regarding capacity utilization, released in tandem with the production data, economists predict a small drop in the rate to 83.4 percent from 83.5 percent in December.
Even though the rate edged up in recent months, the Federal Reserve probably sees little danger of higher prices from potential production bottlenecks, economists said.
The production data are likewise not expected to have any implications for Fed policy, they said.
